deictic contrast: -ov / -on / -ot; the DEFINITE article always attaches enclitically to the first word of the phrase. In this respect it abides to general clitic rules of these languages. The same applies to Bulgarian, however without deictic contrast (only -ot).
It can be singled out for FOCUS and addressed by yes/no questions.

As a RESULTATIVE complement, dào is not always addressable. Compared to wán 'finish', it has a more abstract meaning in many RESULTATIVE constructions. RESULTATIVE complements are referred to as "bound lexical root" (Packard 2011)
This POTENTIAL marker is referred to as an "infix" (Li & Thompson 1981; cf. Packard 2011)
semantic shift: 'get together, meet' > 'understand, know'
Diachronic source: [N] 'blanket, quilt, bedding' > [V] 'wear, cover, recieve, suffer, etc.'

Target Meaning also: COMITATIVE marker; This is a rather weak form of expressing instrumental because the meaning of 'take' is still present. The most prototypical expression for instrumentals is the preposition dûay 'with' as in dûay mîit 'with a knife'.
In this function, tham 'do' is only used with a limited set of stative verbs.
Hây is only used with dynamic verbs. It still has many properties of a control verb.

nán is not a grammaticalized marker of definiteness but it is used in various context for identifying entities which have been activitated in previous discourse.
